resources.string:
When a broadcast is sent, the sender does not receive any indication of what components have received that broadcast, and receivers can read all the data inside the broadcast intent. Moreover, if an implicit intent is used for a broadcast meant for an appâ€™s internal use, that broadcast will be sent to any receiver on the device with a matching filter. Sensitive user information could thus be intercepted and sent to the attacker.


The use of ordered implicit broadcasts can not only enabled eavesdropping as described above, but man in the middle attacks as well.


Ordered broadcasts are sent to receivers one at a time. A malicious app could register a broadcast receiver with a very high priority to ensure it is the first to receive it. It could propagate the broadcast with malicious data replacing the original one, thus performing a Man In the Middle attack. This could be used to corrupt data or crash other applications.


When making a broadcast, the developer can specify the permission that a broadcast receiver needs to have to receive the intent. This can be used to guard against Broadcast Theft. But the malware could still get the permission. Even if the permission is a Signature one, the attacker could get it if they have stolen the developer's certificate. Other ways for a developer to guard against these attacks is to not put sensitive information in a broadcast unless necessary, to use explicit broadcasts for intra-app use, or to send broadcast using LocalBroadcastManager. Alternatively, they could not rely on public broadcast and use one of the newer Android APIs to achieve their goal.

Go to the Call Redirect app and look around. Type in a country code to be added to phone numbers you dial.


Then go to Battery Booster and play around with it. Grant the storage permission it asks for.


Go to the Advanced activity and grant the app the permission it asks for.


Following that, dial a phone number. This number must not include a country code at the beginning! You might then see that dialed number is not the one you typed in, depending on the security level.


NOTE: For unknown reasons, this challenge might not work properly on an Android Emulator. From our experience, on a Pixel 3 emulator with Android 7.1, the dialed phone number does not get replaced even though the malware receiver works correctly. A call will be made to the original phone number, however without the country code. This does not happen on a Huawei P10 Lite, where the challenge works correctly.


NOTE: The phone number that the malware puts instead of the original number is not a valid UK phone number.


If the malware intercepts the broadcast, it will place a flag in its log.

resources.string:
The app listens for public broadcasts sent by the system. Since this app re-writes phone numbers before they are called, it should have a positive low priority, as the documentation for the ACTION_NEW_OUTGOING_CALL intent action says. This is because it should retain any changes made by other receivers.
\n\nHowever, any other app can listen to this broadcast if it has the PROCESS_OUTGOING_CALLS permission. And other receivers can register with a very high priority, receive the broadcast before the targeted app does and read and change the data in the broadcast.

Since the broadcast is sent by the system and not by us, we can not protect it with a permission. One way to increase security is to set the priority level of the broadcast receiver to the maximum possible value, just like the malware does. This way, the receiver of this app will hopefully be called before the malware's receiver. The vulnerable app can then change the number in the broadcast, and then cancel it. The number will still be called because when the broadcast was sent, a final receiver was specified, which gets the broadcast even if another receiver in the chain cancels it.


According to the Android documentation, receivers with the same priority are executed in a random order. From our experience, on devices on Android 7.1 or 8 (API 25 or 26, respectively), receivers are called in alphabetical order of their app package names. This is not guaranteed to be true on other devices.


For this reason, the package name of the malware is abattery_booster, to maximise the chance it will get called first, before the vulnerable app's receiver adds the country code and cancels the broadcast.

Relying on the broadcast receiver with a high priority being called before the receiver of the malware is not a reliable solution, as it depends on the perhaps random order the OS calls the receivers. You could change your app's package name to maximise the change it will come first alphabetically, however that is a hacky solution and it limits they ways you can name your package. Moreover, in the high security level, the broadcast was canceled and thus would not be received any other genuine receiver that needed to process the call.


Therefore, the best solution to fix this vulnerability rests on the user uninstalling the malware. The Battery Booster app asks for a phone permission, when this kind of app should not need this permission. This is a good indicator it is a malicious app.


Uninstall the Battery Booster app to make the call redirection work properly.


Setting the security level to Impossible for this challenge has no effect, it is the same as setting it to low, as the DVM-ICC app can not uninstall the malware for you.

	package="uk.ac.swansea.dascalu.dvmicc.abattery_booster">


	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.KILL_BACKGROUND_PROCESSES" /> 
	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.SYSTEM_ALERT_WINDOW"/> 
	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.PROCESS_OUTGOING_CALLS"/> 
	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.INTERNET"/> 
	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.PACKAGE_USAGE_STATS" /> 
	<uses-permission android:name= 
		"android.permission.READ_EXTERNAL_STORAGE"/>


	<application 
		android:allowBackup="true" 
		android:icon="@mipmap/ic_launcher" 
		android:label="@string/app_name" 
		android:roundIcon="@mipmap/ic_launcher_round" 
		android:supportsRtl="true" 
		android:theme="@style/Theme.DamnVulnerableMobileICC">


		<activity android:name=".MainActivity"> 
			<intent-filter> 
				<action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />

				<category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" /> 
			</intent-filter> 
		</activity> 
		<activity android:name=".AdvancedActivity"/> 
		<activity android:name=".LogActivity"/>


		<receiver android:name=".icc.AppActivityReceiver"> 
			<intent-filter android:priority="2147483647"> 
				<action android:name= 
					"android.intent.action.NEW_OUTGOING_CALL"/> 
			</intent-filter> 
		</receiver>


	</application> 
</manifest>

Ordered broadcasts are delivered to and processed by each matching receiver one at a time. Each receiver can change the result data of the broadcast, or cancel it outright. Receivers can set a priority, and receivers with a higher priority get called first.


Applications that automatically redirect phone calls must listen to a public broadcast that is ordered. Any other application can register to listen to the same broadcast. Therefore, a malicious receiver can register with a very high priority, such that it gets called first, and change the result data.


Ordered broadcasts can be sent with a default receiver, which will always get the broadcast even if it is cancelled by another receiver. That default receiver in this case is the Phone app.


The developer of the Redirect app could set their receiver's priority to the maximum possible value, to get the broadcast before the malware and cancel it so the malware cannot get it. However, that means other legitimate receivers can not get it as well. Moreover, because the malware also has the maximum possible priority, and when two receivers have the same priority, they are called in alphabetical order of their package name, the attacker could set their package name to aaa.aaaaa.aaaa.aa.acpu_booster to make sure the malware receiver always gets called first and replaces the original phone number.


Therefore, the best way to fix this vulnerability rests with the user. In this challenge, the malware can not work if it does not have permission to access phone calls from the user, and the Battery booster app has no obvious reason it would need it. The user should see that the app is suspicious and they should uninstall it.
